ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a whole lot about the creation of different "beings" from Frankenstein's creature to humanoid robots to AIs to trees. We deepened our understanding of what it means to be human in relation to other beings and each developed unique outlooks on our positions in the world.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I definitely loved the diversity of the material we read and watched---Klara and the Sun and The Overstory are now in the bank of all-time favorites. Near the end of the semester, I really liked how Professor Shoemaker sent out emails to guide our thinking before discussion the next day. I definitely think they helped guide my reading a lot better, and as someone more of a silent thinker, it helped me contribute to the discussion more avidly. Paper grades were more than fair and rewarded you for improvement (choosing the higher grade if your paper fell in between two).

One thing that is both a strength and weakness depending on how you look at it is the reading load. There was a lot of reading required for this course, far more than what most of us had previously had to do, which was pretty hard. A lot of the time I couldn't finish the reading in time for our class discussions or had to just skim 100 pages between classes.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. It was definitely the highlight of my semester, and the course takes you to places you didn't think it would (if you told me a course about human limits would touch on trees, I wouldn't have believed you). In class discussions were a lot of fun and getting to meet everyone was incredible. Definitely would take it again, and would highly recommend to any first years looking for a good seminar (especially STEM-based)
I would recommend this class to anyone regardless of whether you're stem or humanities oriented. Anyone can have great discussions and conversations and gain perspective by taking this class.

extras.title: HUMS 037 01/LITR 037 01 - The Limits of the Human
